titleStmt.title: Integrative Analyses of De Novo Mutations Provide Deeper Biological Insights into Autism Spectrum Disorder

analytic.title: Integrative Analyses of De Novo Mutations Provide Deeper Biological Insights into Autism Spectrum Disorder

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

p.s: Highlights d Exome sequencing of Japanese ASD trios supports ''de novo paradigm'' d Integrative analyses were conducted by combining with published DNM data d Integrative analyses confirm and extend ASD-related molecular and brain networks d Integrative analyses identify 61 significant genes as well as drug candidates
Autism spectrum disorders (ASDs) are genetically heterogeneous neurodevelopmental conditions.
Takata et al. analyze de novo mutations (DNMs) in Japanese ASD probands and confirm that the ''de novo paradigm'' is applicable across cohorts of different ethnicities.
They perform integrative analyses of DNMs by combining published datasets, identifying potential disease genes and drug candidates.
DNMs in our and published ASD cohorts (total number of trios, 4,244) and perform integrative bioinformatics analyses.
Besides replicating the findings of previous studies, our analyses highlight ATP-binding genes and fetal cerebellar/striatal circuits.
Analysis of individual genes identified 61 genes enriched for damaging DNMs, including ten genes for which our dataset now contributes to statistical significance.

Screening of compounds altering the expression of genes hit by damaging DNMs reveals a global downregulating effect of valproic acid, a known risk factor for ASDs, whereas cardiac glycosides upregulate these genes.
Collectively, our integrative approach provides deeper biological and potential medical insights into ASDs.

Autism spectrum disorders (ASDs) are a group of neurodevelopmental conditions characterized by impaired social communication and interaction and restricted, repetitive patterns of behavior and interest.
Epidemiological studies have consistently demonstrated that genetic factors play a major role in the etiology of ASDs.

Although this spectrum of disorders is considered to be extremely genetically heterogeneous and attributed to both rare and common genetic variants (Gaugler et al., 2014), recent whole-exome and genome sequencing studies have established a contribution of newly arising de novo mutations (DNMs) to the complex genetic architecture of ASDs (De Rubeis et al., 2014;Dong et al., 2014;Hashimoto et al., 2016;Iossifov et al., 2012Iossifov et al., , 2014;;Neale et al., 2012;O'Roak et al., 2012;Sanders et al., 2012;Turner et al., 2016).

Through the analyses of DNMs and their target genes, a number of previously unrecognized ASD genes as well as molecular pathways and specific developmental timing of brain regions likely involved in the pathogenesis of ASDs have been characterized (De Rubeis et al., 2014;Parikshak et al., 2013;Willsey et al., 2013).

However, at the same time, the number of ASD genes estimated from results of exome analyses was approximately one thousand (Sanders et al., 2012), suggesting that a large number of ASD-linked genes have not yet been determined.

A simple solution to this problem is to increase the sample size, and by utilizing the expanded list of DNMs in a larger study, we would also be able to obtain deeper insights into the biology of ASDs.
Here, we analyze exomes of 262 trios with an ASD proband and their unaffected parents of Japanese origin.
By analyzing properties of DNMs identified in our independent cohort, we prove that the ''de novo paradigm'' is applicable across different ethnicities.

We consequently analyze our dataset and the data of DNMs in published studies jointly to explore ASD genes, molecular pathways, and brain circuits involved in the disease etiology and candidates for therapeutic agents.

The De Novo Paradigm of ASD Is Applicable across Ethnicities We sequenced 262 trios with an ASD proband and unaffected parents of Japanese origin, which were confirmed by multidimensional scaling of genotypes of common exonic SNPs (Figure S1A), at sufficient read coverages (Figure S1B).

After performing variant filtering and confirmatory Sanger sequencing using the analytical pipeline described in Figure S2, we identified a set of high-confidence DNMs (n = 322; the full list of DNMs is available in Table S1).

Based on the variant annotation defined by SnpEff (Cingolani et al., 2012) (see Supplemental Experimental Procedures for details), we classified these DNMs into HIGH-impact (nonsense, splice site, frameshift, and protein-protein contact; note that mutations in known protein-protein interaction loci are by definition classified as HIGH-impact by SnpEff), MODERATE-impact (missense and in-frame insertion or deletion [indel]), and LOW-impact (synonymous) mutations.
In total,58,194, and 70 mutations were classified as having HIGH, MODERATE, and LOW impact, respectively.
We next analyzed these annotated mutations in our cohort together with DNM data from published studies.

There were 3,982 ASD probands and 2,078 unaffected siblings (Kosmicki et al., 2016), originally from three studies (De Rubeis et al., 2014;Dong et al., 2014;Iossifov et al., 2014), re-annotated with the same pipeline as used for our dataset.

By comparing the proportion of individuals carrying one or more HIGH-, MODERATE-, or LOW-impact mutations in the case groups (our ASD cohort,n = 262;published ASD cohort,n = 3,982) with controls (published control cohort of unaffected siblings, n = 2,078), we observed a striking enrichment of HIGH-impact DNM carriers in both our cohort and the published ASD cohort (Figure 1A; p = 2.7 3 10 À7 , odds ratio [OR] = 2.53 in our ASD cohort; p = 4.2 3 10 À9 , OR = 1.65 in the published ASD cohort; 1-tailed Fisher's exact test).

Also, there was a statistically significant enrichment of MODERATE-impact DNM carriers with lower ORs in both case cohorts (Figure 1A; p = 0.020, OR = 1.32 in our ASD cohort; p = 0.00096, OR = 1.18 in the published ASD cohort).

There was no enrichment of LOW-impact mutation carriers in either our cohort or the published cohort (Figure 1A; p = 0.35, OR = 1.07 in our ASD cohort; p = 0.60, OR = 0.99 in the published ASD cohort).
We then stratified HIGH-, MODERATE-, and LOW-impact mutations into subgroups.

We first stratified HIGH-impact DNMs into loss-of-function (LOF) single-nucleotide variants (SNVs; nonsense, splice site, start-loss, or stop-loss mutations), LOF indels (frameshift or start/stop/splice site-disrupting), and mutations in protein-protein interaction (PPI) loci, which are not generally considered LOF mutations but are classified as having HIGH impact by SnpEff (Cingolani et al., 2012).

We confirmed that carriers of LOF SNVs and indels were both significantly enriched in ASD cohorts (Figure 1B; LOF SNV, p = 0.00011, OR = 2.57 in our ASD cohort and p = 1.7 3 10 À6 , OR = 1.76 in the published ASD cohort; LOF indel, p = 0.0057, OR = 1.96 in our ASD cohort and p = 0.0029, OR = 1.40 in the published ASD cohort; 1-tailed Fisher's exact test), indicating that overall enrichment of HIGH -impact DNMs was not driven by indels, whose detection rate would be more pipeline-dependent.

Of note, DNMs in PPI loci independently showed significant enrichment in the published ASD cohort (Figure 1B; p = 0.037, OR = 2.10), and had an OR similar to the other HIGH-impact LOF DNMs in our ASD cohort (Figure 1B; p = 0.12, OR = 2.99).

Although the numbers of this type of DNM were too small (number of DNMs = 3, 33, and 8 in our ASD, published ASD, and control cohort, respectively) to accurately estimate their relative contribution, as represented by wide ranges of 95% confidence intervals of ORs (Figure 1B), our results would provide justification for including DNMs at PPI loci in the HIGH-impact group, as SnpEff does.
Second, we selected missense DNMs more likely to damage gene/protein function and contrasted them with the other MODERATE -impact mutations.

Recent studies of ultra-rare variants, a significant number of which are expected to be de novo or recently generated mutations, in schizophrenia demonstrate that missense variants predicted to be damaging by multiple algorithms are specifically enriched among case subjects (Fromer et al., 2014;Genovese et al., 2016); therefore, we adopted this method and extracted consensus-damaging (CD) missense DNMs predicted to be damaging by all seven algorithms (see Supplemental Experimental Procedures for details).

We observed that carriers of CD missense DNMs were significantly enriched in case cohorts (Figure 1C; p = 0.0050, OR = 1.69 in our ASD cohort; p = 4.3 3 10 À6 , OR = 1.48 in the published ASD cohort), whereas there was no statistically significant enrichment of individuals carrying the other moderate-impact DNMs in our ASD cohort (Figure 1C; p = 0.059, OR = 1.24) and nominally significant enrichment in the published ASD cohort (Figure 1C; p = 0.033, OR = 1.11).

Third, we stratified LOW -impact DNMs into synonymous mutations within 30 bp of the nearest splice site (in coding regions) and potentially affecting exonic splicing regulator (ESR) sequences (ESR-changing near-splice site [nSS]-synonymous DNMs) and the other synonymous mutation, according to recent reports indicating a contribution of these synonymous DNMs (both germline and somatic mutations) to the risk of ASDs (Krupp et al., 2016;Takata et al., 2016).

We observed significant enrichment of individuals carrying one or more ESR-changing nSS-synonymous DNMs in the published ASD cohort (Figure 1D; p = 0.022, OR = 1.28), whereas there was no significant enrichment of carriers of these DNMs in our smaller ASD cohort (Figure 1D; p = 0.43, OR = 1.09).
The other LOW -impact mutations consistently had no significant enrichment among the case cohorts (Figure 1D; p = 0.46, OR = 1.03 in our ASD cohort, p = 0.89, OR = 0.92 in the published ASD cohort).

Although the ORs for these synonymous DNMs that are unlikely to affect splicing were close to one in both cohorts, which is expected for neutral mutations, we observed a slightly higher OR in our cohort (1.03 versus 0.89).
This may reflect a higher overall DNM detection rate in our cohort compared with published datasets.

We therefore performed a logistic regression analysis, testing the relationship between case control status and DNM burden, covariating for the number of synonymous DNMs unlikely to affect splicing as well as sex and depth of exome coverage (when available).

We confirmed that case control status is significantly associated with excesses of HIGH -impact DNMs and MODERATE -impact DNMs, especially CD missense DNMs, in both our cohort and the published ASD cohort when controlling for these covariates (Figures 1E and 1F).

Taken together, these results indicate that genes carrying HIGH -impact or CD missense DNMs, whose highly significant enrichment was consistently observed in both our cohort and the published ASD cohort, are particularly enriched for genuine disease-associated genes.
We subsequently refer to these damaging (HIGH -impact and CD missense) DNMs as ''dDNMs'' and to the genes carrying dDNMs as ''dDNM target genes.''
Analyses of properties of genes hit by putatively deleterious DNMs in published ASD studies have demonstrated enrichment of several specific gene sets.

We tested whether such observations were replicated in our independent dataset of dDNM target genes (N of genes = 98, N of DNMs = 101) using DNENRICH (Fromer et al., 2014), a statistical framework for testing gene set enrichment among DNM-hit genes, accounting for gene size and local tri-nucleotide context.

We evaluated the enrichment of the following previously reported gene sets: fragile X mental retardation protein (FMRP) targets (Darnell et al., 2011), genes involved in chromatin organization (GO:0006325), synaptic genes (Kirov et al., 2012), and genes essential in mice (Georgi et al., 2013; Table S2).

We observed significant enrichment of FMRP targets (p < 1 3 10 À6 ), synaptic genes (p = 0.0023), and genes essential in mice (p = 0.024) among the dDNM target genes in our independent ASD cohort (Table 1).
Although there was no statistically significant enrichment of chromatin regulator genes, we observed a marginal p value for this gene set (Table 1; p = 0.057).

When dDNM target genes in unaffected siblings from previously published studies (N of genes = 387, N of DNMs = 404) were used as the input, there was no significant enrichment of these gene sets (data not shown).

Although a significant relationship between dDNMs and comorbidity of intellectual disability (ID) was not observed in our cohort, probably because of the limited sample size (Supplemental Experimental Procedures; Figure S3), the findings in published studies were overall well replicated in our independent ASD cohort of Japanese origin, both in terms of the global distribution of different functional classes of DNMs and the properties of dDNM target genes.
These results indicate that the de novo paradigm of ASDs is applicable across ethnicities.

Exploratory Gene Ontology Enrichment Analysis of dDNM Target Genes in the Combined Dataset Consistency between our and published datasets of DNMs in ASDs indicates that they can be simply combined and subjected to exploratory analyses (an overview of these analyses is shown in Figure S2).

We therefore performed a gene ontology (GO) enrichment analysis of dDNM target genes in the combined dataset (N of genes = 1,103, N of dDNMs = 1,272) with no prior hypothesis using ToppGene (Chen et al., 2009).

We confirmed that there is enrichment of terms related to neuronal and synaptic function, transcriptional regulation, and chromatin modification (Figure 2; the full result is available in Table S3A), which was reported in a previous large study (De Rubeis et al., 2014).

Specifically, terms relevant to neuronal development and differentiation (e.g., GO:0022008 neurogenesis, Benjamini-Hochberg-corrected p [p BH ] = 2.3 3 10 À12 and GO:0030182 neuron differentiation, p BH = 3.9 3 10 À12 ) formed the largest cluster, which extended to a small cluster of brain development GO terms (e.g., GO:0007420 brain development, p BH = 2.2 3 10 À7 ).

The second-largest cluster included terms of neuronal localization and synaptic signaling (e.g., GO:0097458 neuron part, p BH = 3.1 3 10 À16 and GO:0099537 trans-synaptic signaling, p BH = 2.0 3 10 À8 ), with a branch of terms related to cognition, learning, and behavior (e.g., GO:0050890 cognition, p BH = 6.7 3 10 À9 ).

Enriched terms related to transcriptional regulation and chromatin modification included GO:0045893 positive regulation of transcription, DNAtemplated (p BH = 2.2 3 10 À7 ) and GO:0006325 chromatin organization (p BH = 1.4 3 10 À7 ), respectively.

In addition to these previously reported terms, we found that GO terms related to ATP-binding (e.g., GO:0032559 adenyl ribonucleotide binding, p BH = 3.8 3 10 À12 and GO:0005524 ATP binding, p BH = 4.6 3 10 À12 ) formed the third-largest cluster (Figure 2).
We also found a cluster of GO terms involved in embryo development (e.g., GO:0009790 embryo development, p BH = 7.0 3 10 À11 ).

To confirm that enrichment of these previously not well-described clusters cannot be accounted for by gene sizes and other confounding factors, we subjected the GO terms most significantly enriched in each cluster (GO:0032559 adenyl ribonucleotide binding and GO:0009790 embryo development) to DNENRICH analysis and observed that these terms are highly enriched among dDNM target genes in the combined ASD cohort (p < 1.0 3 10 À6 for both terms; Table S3B).

div.head: An Integrative Analysis of dDNMs and Transcriptome

p.s: Datasets Confirms and Extends Brain Circuits that Are Likely to Be Involved in ASD Etiology By taking advantage of recently developed comprehensive transcriptome atlases across various tissues, cell types, brain regions, and developmental periods, we tested whether the list of ASD dDNMs could inform specific brain regions, developmental timing, and cell types that are likely to be involved in ASD pathogenesis.

We first tested in which human tissue/cell types dDNM target genes in the combined ASD cohort (N of genes = 1,103, N of dDNMs = 1,272) are enriched for genes specifically expressed GO terms enriched among dDNM target genes were identified by a ToppGene analysis (Chen et al., 2009) and then visualized by clustering GO terms according to the similarity of genes contained in each term.
Each node represents an enriched GO term.
Nodes were connected by an edge when the overlap coefficient for the containing genes > 0.7.
Node size represents -log 10 p BH obtained by ToppGene.
Edge width represents the overlap coefficient.
Nodes were color-coded by their belonging cluster labeled with relevant functions/pathways (e.g., neuron development and differentiation).

in each tissue (evaluated by specificity index probability [pSI] statistics) (Dougherty et al., 2010;Xu et al., 2014) using the data of the Genotype-Tissue Expression (GTEx) (GTEx Consortium, 2015; Supplemental Experimental Procedures).

As expected, when we performed a DNENRICH analysis using the list of genes specific to each tissue as the input gene set, we observed that dDNM target genes are significantly enriched for genes specifically expressed in many brain regions, with the highest significance for genes specific to the anterior cingulate cortex (Figure 3A; Table S4A; p BH < 2.7 3 10 À5 ) and global cortex (p BH < 2.7 3 10 À5 ).
Significant enrichment was also observed for genes specifically expressed in the hippocampus, amygdala, basal ganglia, and cerebellum (Figure 3A; Table S4A).
To confirm this and to gain a higher spatiotemporal resolution, we next analyzed human transcriptome data across various brain regions and developmental periods in BrainSpan (BrainSpan, 2011).

We found that dDNM target genes in ASDs are strongly enriched for genes specifically expressed in mid-fetal periods of the cortex (Figure 3B; Table S4B; early mid-fetal, p BH < 6.0 3 10 À5 ; late mid-fetal, p BH = 0.0011), which is consistent with previous studies employing totally different approaches (Parikshak et al., 2013;Willsey et al., 2013; see Discussion for details of the methodological difference).

In addition, statistically significant enrichment was observed for genes specifically expressed in the early mid-fetal striatum (Figure 3B; p BH = 0.0017) and early fetal cerebellum (Figure 3B; p BH = 0.013), in agreement with the global enrichment (regardless of developmental timing) observed in these brain regions by our analysis of GTEx data (Figure 3A; significance for the putamen, nucleus accumbens, and cerebellar hemisphere).

We further explored in which central nervous system (CNS) cell types dDNM target genes are enriched using mouse translating ribosome affinity purification (TRAP) data (Dougherty et al., 2010;Doyle et al., 2008;Heiman et al., 2008).
We observed that dDNM target genes are most significantly enriched for genes specific to Drd1-positive medium spiny neurons of the striatum (Figure 3C; Table S4C; p BH = 0.00022).

Significant enrichment was also observed for genes specific to deep-layer cortical neurons (Figure 3C; Ntsr1-positive layer 6 cortical neurons, p BH = 0.045; Etv1-positive layer 5 cortical neurons, p BH = 0.049), which was again in agreement with the results of previous studies using different methods (Parikshak et al., 2013;Willsey et al., 2013), and cerebellar granule cells (p BH = 0.047).
We also analyzed data of ''modules'' of co-expressed genes in the human cortex; that is, groups of genes that share similar expression patterns during cortical development (Parikshak et al., 2013).

We observed that dDNM target genes are especially enriched for genes included in module 3 (M3) and M16 (Figure 3D; Table S4D; p BH = 0.00044 and 0.00063, respectively) and less strongly in M2 (p BH = 0.022).

div.head: Statistical Analysis of Genes Carrying dDNMs Identifies ASD Genes

p.s: A number of previously unrecognized ASD genes have been discovered through analyses of genes recurrently hit by putatively deleterious DNMs.

We statistically assessed the observed number of dDNMs in each gene using transmission and de novo association test (TADA)-Denovo (He et al., 2013), which employs a hierarchical Bayesian framework to estimate the probability of observing a given number of DNMs per gene.

Prior to performing TADA-Denovo analysis, we devised two procedures to increase the chance of discovering genuine ASD genes: we focused on CD missense DNMs instead of all missense DNMs or those predicted to be damaging by a single algorithm (De Rubeis et al., 2014), and we only included genes with a 90% or more probability of being LOF-intolerant (pLI) (N of genes = 3,467) (Lek et al., 2016), which are highly enriched for known ASD genes (Figure S4B; p = 2.6 3 10 À58 , 1-tailed binomial test) (Supplemental Experimental Procedures).

We first analyzed dDNMs in our Japanese ASD cohort (N of trios = 262; Figure S5; Table S5) and identified three genes significantly enriched for dDNMs (ATP2B2, CHD2, and TRIP12; p BH < 0.05) and one marginally enriched gene (RALA; p BH = 0.051).

We next analyzed the combined dataset (N of trios = 4,244) and found 61 genes significantly enriched for dDNMs, with the highest significance for well-established ASD genes such as CHD8, SYNGAP1, SCN2A, and ANK2 (Figure 4A; Table S5).

In all three genes identified in our smaller cohort with statistical significance (ATP2B2, CHD2, and TRIP12), additional dDNMs were observed in the published ASD cohort, and their statistical significance persisted in the analysis of the combined dataset.
This observation suggests that, even if the size of an analyzed cohort is not very large, genes that reach to the significance threshold are likely to be genuine disease-causative genes.
The RALA gene, which showed marginal enrichment in our cohort, was not included in this list of 61 genes identified in the combined dataset.

When we plotted p values of individual genes before and after combining our dataset, we found that, for ten genes (ATP2B2, MED13L, ANKRD11, GGNBP2, GABRB1, PPP2R5D, DDX3X, MCM6, AGO1, and ATP1A3; shown as magenta dots in Fig- ure 4B), identification of additional dDNMs in our ASD cohort contributed to their statistically significant (p BH < 0.05) enrichment of dDNMs.

In addition, our dataset provides further evidence for TLK2 and NAA15 being neurodevelopmental disorder-related genes that were very recently reported to be disease-causative (Lelieveld et al., 2016;Stessman et al., 2017;Figure 4B).

div.head: Analyses of Genes Co-expressed with Candidate ASD Genes Delineate Their Roles

p.s: The statistical analysis of genes recurrently hit by dDNMs identified ATP2B2, MED13L, ANKRD11, GGNBP2, GABRB1, PPP2R5D, DDX3X, MCM6, AGO1, and ATP1A3 as candidate ASD genes because, for these genes, identification of additional dDNMs in our ASD cohort contributed to their significance.

Of these ten genes, ANKRD11 (Online Mendelian Inheritance in Man [OMIM]: 611192), MED13L (OMIM: 608771), GABRB1 (OMIM: 137190), PPP2R5D (OMIM: 601646), and DDX3X (OMIM: 300160) are already recognized to be involved in neurodevelopmental disorders such as ID and epilepsy.
Among the other five genes, no associated Mendelian disorder was known for ATP2B2, GGNBP2, MCM6, and AGO1.
Although ATP1A3 is known to be linked with other phenotypes, such as dystonia, an association between this gene and ASDs has not been established.

We next analyzed whether these five genes participate in gene networks implicated in ASDs by testing the enrichment of known ASD genes among their co-expression partner genes during human brain development (Supplemental Experimental Procedures).

For this, we stratified the BrainSpan RNA sequencing (RNA-seq) dataset of frontal cortices into 13 developmental periods to construct 11 windows of three consecutive periods (Figure 5A, left), following the method described by Willsey et al. (2013).

By analyzing enrichment in each window, we found that genes positively co-expressed (Pearson's r > 0.8) with ATP2B2, GGNBP2, AGO1, or ATP1A3 were significantly enriched for known ASD genes in one or more windows even after performing stringent multiple-testing correction (Bonferroni procedure considering all hypotheses tested, n = 110) (Figure 5A, right).
For MCM6, we observed significant enrichment of known ASD genes among inversely co-expressed genes in window 1, again after performing Bonferroni correction (Figure 5A, right).

To explore the functional roles of these candidate ASD genes in the co-expression networks, we performed GO enrichment analyses of genes co-expressed with each of the candidate ASD genes (r > 0.8 or < À0.8, not restricted to known ASD genes) in the window with the highest enrichment of known ASD genes (highlighted by the cyan rectangles in Figure 5A; window 1 for MCM6 and ATP1A3, window 6 for ATP2B2, window 9 for GGBNP2, and window 10 for AGO1).

Among genes positively co-expressed (r > 0.8) with ATP2B2 or ATP1A3 and inversely co-expressed (r < À0.8) with MCM6, we observed highly significant enrichment of GO terms related to neuronal localization (Figure 5B; Table S6; e.g., GO:0097458 neuron part, p BH = 2.0 3 10 À40 , 1.6 3 10 À43 , and 4.0 3 10 À21 for ATP2B2, ATP1A3, and MCM6, respectively), synaptic signaling (e.g., GO:0099536 synaptic signaling, p BH = 9.1 3 10 À28 , 1.2 3 10 À20 , and 1.4 3 10 À7 for ATP2B2, ATP1A3, and MCM6, respectively), and development of neurons (e.g., GO:0048666 neuron development, p BH = 2.0 3 10 À10 , 2.4 3 10 À15 , and 1.3 3 10 À12 for ATP2B2, ATP1A3, and MCM6, respectively).

Genes positively co-expressed with GGNBP2 were enriched for GO terms related to post-translational protein modification, such as GO:0016874 ligase activity (p BH = 1.6 3 10 À11 ) and GO:0015031 protein transport (p BH = 1.6 3 10 À10 ) (Figure 5B; Table S6).
Co-expression partners of AGO1 were enriched for GO terms related to chromatin modification (Figure 5B; Table S6; e.g., GO:0051276 chromosome organization, p BH = 6.4 3 10 À8 ).

When interactive networks of genes co-expressed with the candidate ASD genes were visualized by connecting all pairs of genes with positive and inverse correlations (Figure S6, in the windows with the highest enrichment of known ASD genes), we found that the vast majority of connected gene pairs had positive correlations (orange edges in Figure S6); thus, among the genes inversely co-expressed with MCM6, there are many positively co-expressed pairs of genes (Figure S6C).

By looking at individual pairs of co-expressed genes, we identified a number of connections between these candidate ASD genes and well-established ASD genes; for example, ATP2B2 with STXBP1 and SCN2A, GGNBP2 with MECP2 and ANK2, MCM6 with SCN2A and TBR1, AGO1 with POGZ and TSC1, and ATP1A3 with STXBP1 and ARID1B (Figure S6).

Together, these results show that candidate ASD genes coexpressed with known ASD genes in certain developmental windows with robust statistical significance play a role in pathways implicated in ASD pathology (e.g., synaptic signaling and chromatin modification) and interact with established ASD genes, providing biological evidence for these candidates as valid ASD genes.

div.head: Utilization of the Expanded List of dDNMs for Drug Discovery in ASDs

p.s: The expanded list of dDNMs in ASDs would provide an opportunity to identify candidate therapeutic drugs/compounds for ASDs.

We tested which drugs globally up-or downregulate dDNM target genes using connectivity map (CMAP) data (Lamb et al., 2006), a collection of transcriptome data from cultured human cell lines treated with various small (B) Plots of -log 10 p BH for each gene before (p BH -before, x axis) and after (p BH -after, y axis) combining our dataset of Japanese ASDs.
The black dashed lines indicate p BH -before or p BH -after = 0.05.
The pink-shaded area indicates p BH -before > 0.05 and p BH -after < 0.05.
Genes included in this area (ATP2B2, MED13L, ANKRD11, GGNBP2, GABRB1, PPP2R5D, DDX3X, MCM6, AGO1, and ATP1A3) are indicated by the magenta dots with labels.
The cyan dots indicate genes for which both the p BH -before and p BH -after < 0.05.
Among them, genes for which our dataset contributes to further significance (Àlog 10 p BH -after + log 10 p BH -before > 1) are shown with labels (CHD2, TRIP12, NAA15, and TLK2).
molecules, summarized in the Drug Signatures Database (DSigDB) (Yoo et al., 2015;Supplemental Experimental Procedures).
We first statistically assessed overlaps between genes downregulated by a compound (N of compounds = 50) and dDNM target genes in ASDs using DNENRICH (Fromer et al., 2014).

Given that the majority of pathogenic DNMs are expected to induce loss of gene function (Deciphering Developmental Disorders, 2017), it is hypothesized that drugs globally downregulating expression of dDNM target genes are associated with risk of ASDs.

Interestingly, we identified valproic acid, an established maternal risk factor for ASDs (Bromley et al., 2013;Christensen et al., 2013), as one of these drugs (Figures 6A and 6B; Table S7A; p BH = 0.0071, fold change = 2.1).

Other drugs downregulating significantly more dDNM target genes than expected include DNA topoisomerase inhibitors such as doxorubicin (p BH < 7.1 3 10 À6 , fold change = 1.67), daunorubicin (p BH < 7.1 3 10 À6 , fold change = 1.60), and irinotecan (p BH < 7.1 3 10 À6 , fold change = 1.52).
These results are consistent with a recent study (King et al., 2013) implicating DNA topoisomerase in ASD pathology.

We also found that protein kinase inhibitors such as tyrphostin AG-825 (p BH < 7.1 3 10 À6 , fold change = 1.92), staurosporine (p BH < 7.1 3 10 À6 , fold change = 1.89), and GW-8510 (p BH < 7.1 3 10 À6 , fold change = 1.51) downregulated dDNM target genes.
For compounds upregulating expression of dDNM target genes (N of compounds tested = 53), we found seven that upregulated dDNM target genes more significantly than expected (Figure 6C; Table S7A).

Of these, the four drugs with the highest significance, proscillaridin (p BH = 0.00037, fold change = 1.92), lanatoside C (p BH = 0.00037, fold change = 1.85), digoxin (p BH = 0.00037, fold change = 1.94), and helveticoside (p BH = 0.00066, fold change = 1.88), are all cardiac glycosides, which inhibit Na + /K + -ATPase (Figures 6C and 6D).

Genes upregulated by these cardiac glycosides are strongly enriched for GO terms related to nucleosome localization and negative transcriptional regulation (Figure 6E; Table S7B), indicating a previously unknown effect of this drug class on transcription.
In this study, we analyzed exomes of 262 simplex ASD trios of Japanese origin.

Although the overall mutation rate does not seem to greatly differ among ethnic groups, the biological impact of DNMs as well as local mutation rates could be influenced by genetic/genomic backgrounds, epigenetic status, and environmental factors biased by ethnicity.

In addition, diagnostic differences among ethnicities/countries, such as generally higher ASD/autism prevalence in East Asian populations (Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, 2014;Kim et al., 2011;Williams et al., 2006), may significantly influence the relative contribution of DNMs to the genetic and phenotypic architectures of ASDs.
Therefore, it is important to experimentally test whether findings in previous studies mainly analyzing European Americans are replicable in other populations.

In our analyses, we confirmed several key findings in published studies, such as an increase of putatively deleterious DNMs in ASD cases and enrichment of specific gene sets (e.g., FMRP target genes) among the genes hit by DNMs.

These results overall support that the properties of DNMs and their target genes in ASDs are shared between Caucasians and Japanese and indicate that the de novo paradigm of ASD is applicable across ethnicities.
It should be noted, as limitations of our study, that we did not conduct realignment of raw sequencing data and that information regarding paternal age was not available in our dataset.
The results of exploratory analyses of the combined (our and published) list of dDNMs provide several insights into the biology and medical treatment of ASDs.

In the GO enrichment analysis of dDNM target genes, we observed not only an enrichment of synapse-, transcription-, and chromatin-related genes reported in previous studies (De Rubeis et al., 2014;Iossifov et al., 2014) but also of several clusters of GO terms that have not been well described.
Of these, terms related to ATP binding formed a large cluster (Figure 2).

Because it is known that both the synaptic transmission and transcriptional regulation processes are highly energy-consuming (Harris et al., 2012;Wright et al., 2016), dysregulation of ATP metabolism/supply would be the ''root'' of the two representative ASD-related synaptic and transcriptional pathways.

In addition, genes encoding ATPase proteins are reported to be enriched among genes with rare inherited LOF variants in schizophrenia (Takata et al., 2014), which may imply involvement of this pathway in various neuropsychiatric disorders.

Enrichment analyses of dDNM target genes among the genes specifically expressed in each tissue/cell type, brain region, and developmental period convergently point to involvement of mid-fetal cortices, especially layer 5/6 neurons of these regions, in the etiology of ASDs (Figures 3A-3C).

This observation was highly consistent with the results in previous studies (Parikshak et al., 2013;Willsey et al., 2013) (especially with the latter study), demonstrating that the findings are robust to considerable variations in analysis approaches.

Specifically describing methodological differences between our and the Willsey et al. (2013) study, in our analyses, we first constructed lists of genes specific to each developmental timing of a brain region (using the BrainSpan RNA-seq dataset) or each mouse cell type (using data from TRAP studies) and used them as the input for DNENRICH analyses.

On the other hand, Willsey et al. (2013) first constructed networks of co-expressed genes in each developmental window of a brain region (using the BrainSpan microarray dataset), starting with nine high-confidence ASD (hcASD) genes as seeds, and tested whether the constructed networks are enriched for probable ASD genes or layer-specific marker genes identified by using a human microarray dataset (Kang et al., 2011) and a mouse RNA-seq dataset of microdissected samples.

They also reconstructed layer-specific co-expression networks of hcASD genes at mid-fetal periods (using a human microarray dataset of laser-microdissected samples) and evaluated whether the overall connectivity was higher than expected in a specific layer.
Therefore, our and their analyses reached the same conclusion despite using different inputs and data sources, strongly implicating mid-fetal deep-layer neurons in the pathogenesis of ASDs.
We also evaluated the reproducibility of spatiotemporally resolved analyses of ASD-related brain circuits (Supplemental Experimental Procedures; Figure S7).

Besides this confirmatory result, our analyses using GTEx, Brain-Span, and TRAP datasets consistently show that genes specific to fetal periods of cerebellar and striatal neurons are significantly enriched among dDNM target genes.

Although further validation is warranted, our results could extend brain circuits involved in the pathophysiology of ASD, consistent with accumulating evidence showing important roles of cerebellar and striatal circuits in ASDs (Fuccillo, 2016;Wang et al., 2014).

Our statistical evaluation of genes hit by dDNMs using TADA-Denovo identifies 61 ASD genes with statistical significance, including ten genes (ATP2B2, MED13L, ANKRD11, GGNBP2, GABRB1, PPP2R5D, DDX3X, MCM6, AGO1, and ATP1A3) for which identification of additional dDNMs in our cohort contributes to their significance (Figure 4B).
The functional and clinical implications of these genes are discussed in the Supplemental Experimental Procedures.
We also critically evaluated the limitations of our TADA-Denovo analysis, focusing on high-pLI genes (Supplemental Experimental Procedures).
Screening of compounds that induce differential expression of dDNM target genes provides potentially important information.
One notable thing is that we identified valproic acid as one (C) Result of the enrichment analysis of dDNM target genes for genes upregulated by a compound.
(D) Selected compounds upregulating dDNM target genes significantly more than expected.
Lists of genes down-or upregulated by each compound were obtained from CMAP (Lamb et al., 2006) and DSigDB (Yoo et al., 2015).
In (A) and (C), compounds with significant enrichment (p BH < 0.05) are shown as labeled cyan and magenta dots, respectively.
The unlabeled gray dots indicate compounds with no significant enrichment.
The x axes indicate log 2 fold changes (FC; observed number of dDNMs in the differentially expressed genes over the expected number).
The y axes indicate -log 10 p values calculated by DNENRICH (Fromer et al., 2014).
In (B) and (D), Chemical formulas obtained from ChemSpider, p BH , FC, and characteristics/clinical applications of the selected compounds are noted.
And in (E), GO enrichment analysis of genes upregulated by cardiac glycosides is shown.
Bars indicate p BH .
The red line indicates p BH = 0.05.
The most significantly enriched ten terms are shown.
of the drugs globally downregulating dDNM target genes (Figure 6A).

Because maternal use of valproic acid is one of the most established environmental risk factors for ASDs in the offspring (Bromley et al., 2013;Christensen et al., 2013), our analysis could correctly identify the best ''positive control'' drug.
In addition to valproic acid, we found that several DNA topoisomerase inhibitors (Figure 6A; e.g., doxorubicin, daunorubicin, and irinotecan) commonly downregulate dDNM target genes.
This finding is consistent with a recent study reporting that DNA topoisomerase inhibitors downregulate many known ASD genes by impairing transcriptional elongation (King et al., 2013).

These results, identifying drugs that have been implicated in ASD risk, raise the possibility that drugs with an opposite effect (i.e., those globally upregulating dDNM targets) could have therapeutic potential.
Interestingly, we found that cardiac glycosides (proscillaridin, lanatoside C, digoxin, and helveticoside) commonly upregulate more dDNM target genes than expected (Figures 6C and 6D).
GO enrichment analysis of genes upregulated by these drugs reveals their effects on nucleosome modification and transcriptional regulation (Figure 6E).
According to these observations, it would be worthwhile to further pursue these drugs' therapeutic potential.

Nevertheless, it would be too optimistic to assume that global upregulation of ASD-related genes will be of benefit without major adverse effects, especially given the complex neurodevelopmental landscape on which ASDs arise.
Therefore, our findings must not be directly translated into clinical settings.
As indicated by the results of this study, gene expression-modifying agents will probably need spatial, temporal, and cell type specificity.
Investigations considering such specificity using various developmental stages of model animals and/or multiple cell lines would be a good first step when addressing this complexity.
In summary, in this study, we performed integrative analyses incorporating various datasets and bioinformatics tools.

By adding up exome data of several hundreds of ASD trios, we successfully identified multiple previously unrecognized ASD genes supported not only by statistical evidence but also by the presumed biological roles of these genes.
Our results also consolidate and extend our knowledge of the molecular pathways and brain circuits implicated in ASDs and provide potentially important information for drug discovery.

These results demonstrate the usefulness of such integrative approaches, and, importantly, our dataset will be a part of further large-scale unified analyses in the near future, which are mandatory to complete the catalog of ASD genes and to establish better treatments.
Further details and an outline of resources used in this work can be found in the Supplemental Experimental Procedures.
DNA samples of 262 patients with ASD (all more than 2 years old, 191 males and 71 females) and their unaffected parents were collected at the participating institutions/hospitals.
Detailed information regarding diagnostic and quality control procedures is available in the Supplemental Experimental Procedures.
Written informed consent was obtained from all participants.
The study protocols were approved by the institutional review boards of Yokohama City University School of Medicine and participating sites.
Enrichment of dDNMs in ASDs was evaluated by Fisher's exact test or logistic regression analysis.
Gene set enrichment analysis of dDNM targets was performed by using DNENRICH (Fromer et al., 2014).
Statistical evaluation of genes hit by dDNMs was performed by using TADA-Denovo (He et al., 2013).
Detailed information is available in the Supplemental Experimental Procedures.
Contact for Reagent and Resource Sharing Please contact N.M. (naomat@yokohama-cu.ac.jp) for reagents and resources generated in this study.
The accession number for the variant data reported in this paper is Human Genetic Variation Database (HGVD): HGV0000007.
Supplemental Information includes Supplemental Experimental Procedures, seven figures, and seven tables and can be found with this article online at https://doi.org/10.1016/j.celrep.2017.12.074.
Figure 1.
Enrichment Analyses of Various Functional Types of DNMs in Our and Published ASD Cohorts The red and blue bars indicate ORs for each type of DNMs in our and published ASD cohorts, respectively.
(A) An enrichment analysis stratifying DNMs according to the SnpEff annotations (HIGH-, MODERATE-, and LOW-impact mutations).
(B) An analysis stratifying HIGH-impact DNMs into LOF SNVs, LOF indels, and DNMs in protein-protein interaction (PPI) loci.

(C) An analysis stratifying MODERATE-impact DNMs into missense mutations predicted to be damaging by all of the seven algorithms (consensus-damaging [CD] missense; Supplemental Experimental Procedures) and others.

(D) An analysis stratifying LOW-impact mutations into synonymous DNMs that are within 30 bp of the nearest splice site (in exons) and changing exonic splicing regulator (enhancer or silencer) sequences (ESR-changing nSS; Supplemental Experimental Procedures) and the other synonymous DNMs.
The p values were calculated by 1-tailed Fisher's exact tests and are shown above the bars.
Error bars indicate 95% confidence intervals.

(E and F) Results of logistic regression analyses testing the relationship between case control status and the burden of each type of DNMs (MutationCount), covariating for; the number of non-ESR-changing nSS synonymous DNMs (low_others: mutations expected to be neutral) in each individual, mean depth of exome coverage (DoC) and sex (E), or the number of non-ESR-changing nSS synonymous DNMs in each individual and sex (F).
Figure 2. Visualization of Clusters of GO Terms Enriched among dDNM Target Genes in the Combined Dataset of ASDs

Figure 3. Enrichment Analyses of dDNM Target Genes Incorporating Various Transcriptome Datasets (A) Analyses testing the enrichment of dDNM target genes for genes specifically expressed in one of the tissue/cell types in GTEx.
Uncorrected p values obtained by DNENRICH are shown as bar plots.
Bars are color-coded by the annotated system (brain, cardiovascular, digestive, endocrine, reproductive, or others).
The gray dashed line indicates the approximate significance threshold after Benjamini-Hochberg correction (corrected p = 0.05).(B)
Analyses testing enrichment for genes specifically expressed in a developmental period of a brain region (using the BrainSpan dataset).
(C) Analyses testing enrichment for genes specifically expressed in a mouse CNS cell type.
(D) Analyses testing enrichment for genes in a co-expression module constructed from human cortex transcriptome data.
M7, representing the set of genes not strongly co-expressed with other genes in the original publication(Parikshak et al., 2013), was not included in the analysis.
In (B)-(D), cells are color-coded according to p BH .
Asterisks indicate p BH < 0.05.
Figure ASD Genes with Significant Enrichment of dDNMs(A) Manhattan plot of -log 10 p BH for each gene, representing enrichment of dDNMs.
The p values were obtained from the analysis of the combined (our and published) dataset using TADA-Denovo(He et al., 2013).
The red line indicates p BH = 0.05.
Genes with p BH < 0.05 are labeled with their gene symbols.
(B) Plots of -log 10 p BH for each gene before (p BH -before, x axis) and after (p BH -after, y axis) combining our dataset of Japanese ASDs.
The black dashed lines indicate p BH -before or p BH -after = 0.05.
The pink-shaded area indicates p BH -before > 0.05 and p BH -after < 0.05.
Genes included in this area (ATP2B2, MED13L, ANKRD11, GGNBP2, GABRB1, PPP2R5D, DDX3X, MCM6, AGO1, and ATP1A3) are indicated by the magenta dots with labels.
The cyan dots indicate genes for which both the p BH -before and p BH -after < 0.05.
Among them, genes for which our dataset contributes to further significance (Àlog 10 p BH -after + log 10 p BH -before > 1) are shown with labels (CHD2, TRIP12, NAA15, and TLK2).
Figure 5. Analyses of Genes Co-expressed with Candidate ASD Genes during Development of the Frontal Cortex(A) Left: description of the developmental periods used in our analyses.
PCW, post-conception week.

Right: enrichment analyses of known ASD genes (categories S, 1, 2, and 3 of SFARI genes) among the genes positively and inversely co-expressed with each of the five candidate ASD genes (ATP2B2, GGNBP2, MCM6, AGO1, or ATP1A3).
Cells are color-coded by Bonferroni-corrected p values according to the number of all hypotheses tested in this analysis (5 genes 3 11 windows 3 two directions of correlation = 110).
For developmental windows with significant enrichment of ASD genes (Bonferronicorrected p < 0.05), fold changes (observed/expected numbers of ASD genes) are shown.
For each gene, the window with the highest enrichment of known ASD genes is highlighted by a cyan rectangle.
(B) GO enrichment analyses of genes co-expressed with each of the five candidate ASD genes in the windows with the highest enrichment.
Bars indicate p BH .
The red lines indicate p BH = 0.05.
The most significantly enriched ten terms are shown.
